DOC.HEAD: Grain Futures Drift Lower
DOC.TEXT: Most grain and soybean futures prices drifted lower in light early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Trading volume was thin and activity slow, typical for a pre-holiday period. ``The main characteristic of the market today is its quiet, dull trade _ it's directionless,'' said Victor Lespinasse, a floor trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Rainfall overnight in Brazil, the world's second-largest soybean producer, kept pressure on soybean futures prices. Traders seemed to ignore the continuing frigid weather in the Great Plains and Midwest, which helped commodity prices last week. The Agriculture Department's rejection of wheat export bids from Morocco and Egypt added another bearish factor while indications that India is in the market for palm oil were perceived as helpful to the soybean oil market. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent lower to { cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $4.14} a bushel; corn was { cent to } cent lower with December at $2.34 a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2 cents lower with December at $1.40 a bushel; soybeans were { cent to 1{ cents lower with January at $5.79} a bushel. Cattle futures were mixed while pork futures were lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .32 cent lower to .18 cent higher with December at 78.45 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .23 cent lower to .08 cent higher with January at 84.40 cents a pound; live hog futures were .10 cent to .35 cent lower with December at 53.10 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .05 cent to .70 cent lower with February at 51.65 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled mixed on Monday while pork futures advanced.
